questions.text: A 49-year-old female presents with a unilateral bloody nipple discharge. On examination, a small, palpable mass beneath the areola is noted. A core needle biopsy is performed, and the histopathology report is as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of unilateral bloody nipple discharge with a palpable mass beneath the areola and histopathology showing a central fibrovascular core with papillae arborizing within the lumen are suggestive of a solitary intraductal papilloma.  

Intraductal papilloma is a benign, proliferative breast disorder without atypia. It can be solitary or multiple (papillomatosis). Most commonly seen in premenopausal women.

Option A. Ductal carcinoma in situ: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a neoplastic proliferation of epithelial cells limited by the basement membrane. It involves the ducts and lobules. It is not associated with a loss of E-cadherin expression. It typically presents as a suspicious area on a mammogram rather than a palpable mass with bloody discharge.

Option C. Lobular carcinoma in situ: Histologically, LCIS consists of a monomorphic population of cells with oval or round nuclei and small nucleoli involving ducts and lobules. Mucin-positive signet ring cells are commonly present. The histological image is given below:

Option D. Fibroadenoma: This is a benign breast tumor that is usually firm, rubbery, and mobile. They occur in women in their 20s and 30s, and they are frequently multiple and bilateral. Histology shows delicate and often myxoid stroma that resembles normal intralobular stroma. The epithelium may be surrounded by stroma (pericanalicular pattern) or compressed and distorted by it (intracanalicular pattern) as shown below:

questions.text: Oil red O stain is used in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Oil red O (ORO) stain is used in frozen section.

Oil red O stains lipid/ fats and gives a characteristic orange/red appearance. It is used in the unfixed frozen sections as the fixation of fats with other routine processes may lose the lipid content. 10% Neutral buffer formaldehyde (NBF) is the preferred fixative in histopathological sections staining with Oil red O. Zenker's fixative and Helly's fixative are best avoided during staining with ORO.

Oil red O stains the lipid in the vacuoles in the pulmonary vasculature. It can be useful in identifying fat emboli in lung tissue, diagnosing renal cell carcinoma, and sebaceous gland tumors of the skin.

 Other stains used for lipids or fats:

  • Nile blue sulfate The preferred fixative is formal calcium.
  • Osmic acid is used in the frozen section. 10% NBF is the preferred fixative
  • Sudan black B is used in the frozen section. The preferred fixative is 10% NBF.

Other Options:

Option A: Formalin fixation- Formalin as 10% neutral buffered formalin (NBF) is the most common fixative used in diagnostic pathology.

Option C: Ethyl alcohol- Ideal fixative for cytological smears because it acts quickly and gives good nuclear detail.

Option D: Glutaraldehyde- Preferred fixative in electron microscopy. The standard solution is a 2.5% buffered glutaraldehyde.

questions.text: A patient comes to the clinic complaining of recurrent oral and genital ulcers. Further evaluation shows an association with the HLA -B51 haplotype. Identify the likely diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The presentation of a patient with recurrent oral aphthous ulcers and genital ulcers, associated with HLA haplotype B51 is likely to be a diagnosis of Behcet disease.

Behcet disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. Here (Th17) T helper 17 cells play an important contribution in the recruitment of neutrophils, which will later infiltrate into the vessel wall. 

There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms. The condition is treated with steroids, cyclophosphamide, and TNF antagonists.

Other options:

Option A: Goodpasture's syndrome is an anti-GBM (glomerular basement membrane) antibody-mediated disease. The antibodies are directed against the non-collagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV. As it is present in both the alveoli and GBM, it usually presents with pulmonary hemorrhage and renal failure.

Option B: Takayasu arteritis is the inflammation of the medium to large-sized arteries. It mainly affects the aortic arch and its branches. The most commonly affected artery is the subclavian artery. Patients will present with features of arm claudication, Raynaud's phenomenon, etc. They can also present with syncope, transient ischemic attack, abdominal pain, or chest pain depending on the arteries involved. A biopsy of the affected artery will show pan arteritis with mononuclear cell infiltrates and occasionally giant cells. Takayasu arteritis is not associated with migratory thrombophlebitis.

Option D: Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis of multiple organs. The clinical features include non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss. The pulmonary findings are characterized by severe asthmatic attacks and pulmonary infiltrates. Renal disease is less common in these patients. These patients show p-ANCA positivity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with HIV presents with generalized edema and proteinuria. He has had a gradual decline in renal function over the past year. Renal biopsy shows the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an HIV-positive man presenting with edema, proteinuria, and renal biopsy findings showing segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the glomeruli is suggestive of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). 

FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is characterized by degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells and effacement of foot processes. Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis are seen due to the entrapment of plasma proteins and increased extracellular matrix deposition.

FSGS on pathology is associated with sclerosis of some, but not all, glomeruli (focal). In the affected glomeruli, only a portion of the capillary is involved (segmental). Immunofluorescence microscopy shows deposition of IgM and C3 in the sclerotic areas.

FSGS can occur as a primary disease (idiopathic) or in association with other conditions. These conditions include:

  • HIV
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Morbid obesity
  • Heroin addiction

questions.text: An autopsy of a 38-year-old male patient who died of cardiac failure showed the following histopathological image of the endocardium. Which of the following best describes the form of vegetation found in this condition?

choices.text: Small, warty vegetations along the line of closure of the valve leaflets
Large, irregular masses on valve cusps and chordae
Small, bland vegetations on the line of closure
Small to medium sized vegetations on either sides of the valve

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with histopathology showing Anitschkow cells and Aschoff bodies are pathognomic of the rheumatic fever (RF) phase of rheumatic heart disease (RHD). It is associated with small, warty vegetations along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets.

RF is an acute, immunologically mediated, multisystem inflammatory disease classically occurring a few weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. RHD is principally characterized by deforming fibrotic valvular disease, particularly the mitral valve.

Important pathological findings in rheumatic fever are:

  • Inflammation in the three layers of the heart can result in endocarditis, myocarditis, pericarditis, or pancarditis.
  • Inflammation of the endocardium and the left side valves can lead to fibrinoid necrosis. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations can be seen along the lines of closure, called verrucae.
  • In the subendocardium, irregular thickenings called MacCallum plaques can be present.
  • Aschoff bodies are collections of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), scattered plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages (called Anitschkow cells). The Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence they are also called caterpillar cells.
  • Mitral valve in chronic RHD shows leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords.This leads to narrowing of the mitral orifice, giving it a fish mouth appearance.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent lung infections and thick mucus secretions. Chest x-ray shows bronchiectasis in bilateral upper lobes. What is the most common mutation seen in these patients?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with recurrent lung infection with thick mucus secretion and upper lobe bronchiectasis suggest the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. The most common mutation in cystic fibrosis is Phe508del. 

Cystic fibrosis or mucoviscidosis is an autosomal recessive disorder with a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion.

CFTR gene encodes for ATP-gated chloride channels in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. It regulates the flow of ions across epithelial membranes of sweat glands, respiratory airways, pancreatic ducts, etc. The defect leads to high salt concentrations in sweat and viscous luminal secretions in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.

Clinical manifestations/ complications of cystic fibrosis include:
  • Sinusitis and nasal polyps
  • Respiratory - copious hyper-viscous and adherent pulmonary secretions with abnormal mucociliary clearance obstruct small and medium-sized airways leading to respiratory compromise. The disease can be further complicated by bronchiectasis and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).
  • Gastrointestinal - 
    • Thick and adherent exocrine secretions obstruct pancreatic ducts and impair the production and flow of digestive enzymes
    • Tissue destruction of the exocrine pancreas, with fibrotic scarring, cyst proliferation, and loss of acinar tissue - fat malabsorption, steatorrhea, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies
    • Obstruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and parenchymal fibrosis leading to hepatic insufficiency and focal biliary cirrhosis
    • Distal intestinal obstructive syndrome in adults and meconium ileus in neonates
  • Reproductive - males have infertility due to the congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens and defective sperm transport, resulting in obstructive azoospermia. Females have infertility due to abnormalities of the reproductive tract secretions.

 The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of
    • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
    • Positive newborn screening or
    • A sibling with cystic fibrosis
  • Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by
    • Two positive sweat chloride test results were obtained on separate days or
    • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
    • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference

Cystic fibrosis requires a multidisciplinary approach to management. The correction of the defect can be done via:

  • Lumacaftor, an FDA-approved drug that corrects the misfolding and reverts the Phe508del mutation defect
  • Ivacaftor potentiates CFTR channel opening and stimulates ion transport

End-stage pulmonary failure requires lung transplantation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man diagnosed with Huntington's chorea has a family history of the disease. Which of the following best explains the earlier onset of the disease in successive generations?
questions.solution:
Genetic anticipation explains the earlier onset of the disease in successive generations.

Genetic anticipation is a phenomenon observed in certain trinucleotide repeat disorders like Huntington's disease. In these disorders, the number of CAG repeats in a specific gene increases with each generation, leading to earlier onset and more severe symptoms in offspring.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (“striate neurons”) caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the Huntingtin gene (chromosome 4), which results in chorea and dementia and which demonstrates anticipation.

The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, cortex, and hydrocephalus ex vacuo of the 3rd ventricle.

This is commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decade of life and motor problems like chorea precede dementia. Treatment consists of haloperidol and tetrabenazine for chorea.

Other options:

Option A: Somatic mutations are acquired mutations that occur in somatic cells and are not passed on to offspring. They cannot explain the pattern of inheritance seen in this case.

Option B: Incomplete penetrance refers to variations in penetrance and expressivity of clinical features. Not all individuals who inherit the mutant gene show a mutant phenotype. It is a feature of autosomal dominant disorders.   

Option D: Mitochondrial inheritance has its unique patterns of inheritance, passed exclusively from females, that do not match the observed scenario.

questions.text: The following is a histopathological image of the thyroid mass. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, which are findings suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells. Most of MTC are sporadic. Some are associated with inheritable syndromes like familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B, all of which are secondary to RET gene mutations.

Most patients present at 50–60 years and have a female preponderance. MTC secretes calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH).

Features of MTC

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea if there is local invasion
  • Diarrhoea due to increased intestinal motility
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Blood-borne metastasis 

Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid stroma. Raised calcitonin and CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass helps in diagnosis.

Other options:

Option B: The image below shows Orphan Annie-eye nuclei with central clearing and margination of chromatin in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Option C: Follicular carcinoma thyroid on histopathology may show uniform cells forming small follicles containing colloid (resembling normal thyroid gland) or sheets of cells without colloid.

Option D: Anaplastic carcinomas are poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas with varied morphology, including giant cells or spindle-shaped cells or both. There is minimal follicular differentiation with intratumoral necrosis.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

  • Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma.
  • Most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 
  • Mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade; more common in women than men (2:1)
  • Usually cold nodule on the scan
  • Branching papillae and follicles with the fibrovascular stalk, Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes: Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, pseudo-inclusions, nuclear grooves.
  • Lymph node metastasis is common
  • Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma.
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion
  • Most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain
  • Excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346) are associated with follicular carcinoma

Histology:

  • Usually solitary lesion
  • Encapsulated
  • Has uniform micro follicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumor thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere.

The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumor recurrence because this thyroid protein should be barely detectable in a patient who is free of disease.

questions.text:
Match the following cell types with their associated malignancy.
1. Popcorn cell a. Acute promyelocytic leukemia
2. Faggot cell b. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
3. Cerebriform nuclei c. Burkitt lymphoma
4. Starry sky d. Sezary syndrome
questions.solution:
The correct matches are 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c.

1. Popcorn cell b. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
2. Faggot cell a. Acute promyelocytic leukemia
3. Cerebriform nuclei d. Sezary syndrome
4. Starry sky c. Burkitt lymphoma

 

Popcorn cell is a lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant of Reed Steenberg (RS) cells that are characteristic of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma. It has a delicate multilobed, puffy nucleus resembling popped corn. The image below shows a popcorn cell seen in lymphocytic predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks are known as faggot cells and are highly suggestive of acute promyelocytic leukemia. Histopathology from bone marrow aspirate reveals numerous Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes. Faggot cells are shown below.


Mycosis fungoides is cutaneous T cell lymphoma which usually stays confined to the skin. It can disseminate into blood which is known as Sezary syndrome.  Histological hallmark includes:

  • Pautrier's microabscesses - tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters.
  • Epidermotropism - invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis.
  • Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane).

The image shows sezary cells with cerebriform nuclei in the peripheral smear.


Microscopy in Burkitt lymphoma shows a characteristic starry sky pattern. The neoplastic cells are homogeneous, medium-sized B cells with frequent mitotic figures and reactive macrophages scattered through the tumor, with their pale cytoplasm in a background of blue-staining tumor cells giving the tumor a so-called "starry sky" appearance.

The image given below shows a starry sky pattern seen in Burkitt lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following mutations is not seen in patients with renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
MSH2 mutation is not associated with renal cell carcinoma.

Renal cell carcinoma can be sporadic or inherited. Various mutations are implicated in familial cancers. The most common mutation is VHL mutation (clear cell RCC).

Other mutations that can cause renal cell carcinoma include MET mutation (Papillary type RCC), BHD mutation (Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome), and Xp11 translocation (a subtype that occurs in young patients due to overexpression of TFE3 transcription factor).

MSH2 mutation results in DNA mismatch repair which causes colon cancers including familial hereditary nonpolyposis colon carcinoma and endometrial cancers.

questions.text: Bronchoscopic examination of a 55-year-old non-smoker woman confirmed the presence of lung carcinoma. On biopsy, a lepidic pattern was observed. Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a non-smoker woman presenting with cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, and lung biopsy showing a lepidic pattern (butterfly on the fence) is suggestive of adenocarcinoma of the lung. The paraneoplastic syndromes associated with this include hypertrophic osteoarthropathy and migratory venous thrombophlebitis.

Migratory venous thrombophlebitis is a paraneoplastic syndrome also known as Trousseau’s syndrome or Trousseau's sign of malignancy. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of localized thrombosis of the superficial veins of limbs. It can lead to tender and erythematous rashes.

Migratory thrombophlebitis is seen in pancreatic cancer (most common), lung cancer, gastrointestinal cancer, ovarian cancer, prostate cancer, and in lymphomas. 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer seen in women and nonsmokers. Adenocarcinomas are usually located in the periphery compared to other lung tumors and are relatively smaller. Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia is a precursor lesion of adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemical markers in adenocarcinoma lung are thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) and napsin A.

Microscopic examination shows a lepidic pattern of growth at the periphery of the tumor. The tumor cells appear to crawl along the normal-appearing alveolar septa, as shown in the image below.

Note: Trousseau’s sign is seen in hypocalcemia where there is an involuntary contraction of the muscles of the hand and wrist when a blood pressure cuff is placed on the arm and inflated to 20mm of Hg above systolic blood pressure.

questions.text: A female patient presented with complaints of bloody urine mostly during the night time. Laboratory investigations show pancytopenia and elevated LDH levels. Ham's test was found to be positive. What is the gold standard investigation done for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of bloody urine during the night, pancytopenia, elevated LDH levels, and positive Ham test are suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) and flow cytometry is the gold standard investigation.

PNH is a chronic acquired hemolytic anemia that occurs due to mutations in the PIGA gene. PIGA is an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins.

Thus, PNH blood cells are deficient in three glycosylphosphatidylinositols (GPI) linked proteins that regulate complement activity:

  • Decay accelerating factors or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis or CD59
  • C8 binding protein

Clinically, the patient would have hemolysis, pancytopenia, and a tendency for venous thrombosis. Intravascular hemolysis may be nocturnal and paroxysmal or chronic hemolysis without the dramatic hemoglobinuria. Blood investigations reveal iron deficiency anemia (due to chronic hemoglobinuria) and elevated LDH levels.

Investigations in PNH include:

  • Flow cytometry (gold standard) - deficiency of CD59 and CD55
  • Ham test (acidified serum lysis) - lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH due to complement fixation
  • Bone marrow biopsy -
    • Hypercellularity with erythroid hyperplasia is seen in classical presentations
    • Patients who develop pancytopenia will have hypocellular bone marrow
  • Imaging - to evaluate venous thrombosis

Treatment involves the use of eculizumab, a monoclonal antibody that prevents the conversion of the complement C5 to C5a.

Other options:

Option B: Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is obtained by assessing the staining intensity in 100 consecutive neutrophils, with each neutrophil scored on a scale of 1–4. Conditions that result in an increase in leukocytes in all stages of maturity will reflect a corresponding increase in LAP. LAP is increased in leukemoid reaction and decreased in CML, and hence helps to differentiate the two.

Option C: Coombs test detects antibodies against blood components, and is positive in autoimmune causes of anemia.

Option D: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH) helps in the detection of specific genetic information on morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes. FISH can be performed on prenatal samples, peripheral blood cells, touch preparations from cancer biopsies, and even fixed archival tissue sections. It is used to detect chromosomal aneuploidy, subtle microdeletions and rearrangements, complex translocations, and gene amplification.

questions.text: Which female genital cancer is associated with metabolic disturbances like diabetes, obesity, and hypertension?
questions.solution:
Endometrial cancer has been found to be associated with metabolic disturbances like diabetes, obesity, and hypertension.

Endometrial carcinoma is the most common invasive cancer of the female genital tract. Type 1 endometrial carcinoma shows endometrioid morphology and is associated with the following:

  • Unopposed estrogen exposure (endometrial hyperplasia)
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypertension

The tumor-suppressor gene PTEN is mutated in approximately 20% of endometrial hyperplasias.

Genomic sequencing of endometrial carcinoma has revealed 4 major molecular subtypes of endometrioid and serous carcinomas:

  • Ultramutated/POLE tumors - mutations in DNA polymerase ε (POLE)
  • Hypermutated/MSI (microsatellite instability) tumors - mutations involving mismatch repair genes
  • Copy number low/MSS (microsatellite stable) tumors - mutations involving the PI3K/AKT pathway
  • Copy number high/serous-like tumors - TP53 mutations and numerous genomic copy number variants

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with a history of easy bruisiability and hemarthrosis. Investigations revealed normal platelet count and bleeding time, normal PT, and prolonged PTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hemarthrosis and the investigations showing prolonged PTT  and normal platelet count, bleeding time, and PT, are suggestive of a coagulation disorder. Among the given options, hemophilia A is a coagulation disorder, while all the other conditions are platelet disorders.

Bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) and deep tissues is a feature of coagulation disorders, whereas platelet disorders usually present with mucocutaneous bleeding such as petechiae, purpura, epistaxis, or GI bleeding. Prolonged PT/aPTT is a feature of coagulation disorders, while prolonged bleeding time is a feature of platelet disorders.

In the given scenario, normal platelet count and bleeding time exclude platelet disorders. Normal PT indicates normal functioning of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, and prolonged PTT indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway.

Hemophilia is an X-linked (recessive) coagulation disorder associated with mutations in factor VIII, affecting the intrinsic pathway. The patients present with easy bruising, significant hemorrhage following trauma and operative procedures, and hemarthroses, but no petechiae. The diagnosis is confirmed by carrying out factor VIII-specific assays. Infusions of recombinant factor VIII are used for treatment. 

Other options:

Option 1- Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant disorder that is associated with qualitative/quantitative defects in the von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is a protein necessary for platelet adhesion, platelet aggregation, and stabilization of factor VIII.

Option 3- Bernard-Soulier disease is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIb receptor necessary for platelet adhesion to the subendothelial collagen. 

Option 4- Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor necessary for platelet aggregation.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue and chronic diarrhea for 4 months. Endoscopy reveals several ulcers in the gastric antrum and the descending duodenum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gastrinoma- Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. 

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors. In 75% of patients, gastrinomas are sporadic, solitary lesions. The remaining 25% of patients with gastrinomas have multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1). Gastrinomas usually arise in the small intestine or pancreas. The most remarkable feature in the stomach is an increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

Patients present with duodenal ulcers or chronic diarrhea. Ulcers may occur in unusual locations such as the jejunum; when intractable jejunal ulcers are found, Zollinger-Ellison syndrome should be considered. 

Treatment of individuals with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome includes blockade of acid hypersecretion, typically with proton pump inhibitors. 

Other options:

Option A: VIPoma is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome). It is caused by the release of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) from the tumor.

Option C: Glucagonomas, α-cell tumors are associated with increased serum levels of glucagon. The patient presents with mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia. They occur most frequently in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women and are characterized by extremely high plasma glucagon levels.

Option D: Insulinomas, β-cell tumors are the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasms. These are usually benign and often cause symptomatic hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemic symptoms appear when blood glucose levels fall below 50 mg/dL. The symptoms usually develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake.

 

Related Pearl: Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

  • Unregulated gastrin release from a non β cell endocrine tumor (gastrinoma)
  • Gastrinomas may be sporadic (M/C) or may be associated with MEN 1 syndrome
  • Females are more commonly affected, between 30-50 years
  • Long-standing hypergastrinemia leads to hyperchlorhydria
  • Peptic ulcer is the most common clinical manifestation
  • Clinical situations that should create suspicion of gastrinoma:
    • Ulcers in unusual locations (second part of the duodenum and beyond)
    • Refractory ulcers
    • Postoperative ulcer recurrence
    • Ulcers presenting with frank complications
    • Ulcers in the absence of H. pylori or NSAID ingestion
  • Diarrhoea is seen in 50% patients
  • The first step in evaluation is to obtain a fasting gastrin level
  • A BAO >15meq/h in the presence of hypergastrinemia is considered pathognomonic of ZES
  • BAO/MAO > 0.6 (BAO = basal acid output) (MAO=maximal acid output)
  • PPIs are the treatment of choice

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady comes with complaints of fever, abdominal pain, and itching over her arms and legs. On examination, icterus and mild hepatomegaly are seen. Liver function tests show deranged values with elevated serum IgG levels. The patient also tests negative for viral hepatitis markers. Which of the following characteristic histopathological features suggests the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with increased serum IgG levels and absence of viral hepatitis markers indicate autoimmune hepatitis (AIH).  The characteristic histopathological picture seen in AIH is a cluster of plasma cells and lymphocytes at the interface between the portal tract and liver lobule is known as interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis

Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterized by extensive inflammation, fibrosis, and ultimately cirrhosis. The pathologic features include:

  • Emperipolesis - Lymphocytes and plasma cells within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes.
  • Interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis.
  • Rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration.

Below is a histopathological image of AIH.

The simplified scoring system for the diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis includes four variables. They are:

  1. Autoantibodies
  2. Elevated serum IgG level
  3. Typical compatible histologic features
  4. Absence of viral hepatitis markers

A small number of drugs such as minocycline, nitrofurantoin, and α-methyldopa can trigger the formation of autoantibodies and hepatocellular injury that mimics autoimmune hepatitis.

Other options:

Option A: Ground glass hepatocytes are characteristically found in Hepatitis B and are a diagnostic hallmark.

Option B: Bile duct injury and granulomas are uncommon except in case of overlap with primary biliary cirrhosis.

Option C: Councilman bodies are seen in acute viral hepatitis. They are apoptotic hepatocytes that are deeply eosinophilic stained.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with swelling in the upper diaphyseal part of the tibia. X-ray of the swelling showed a periosteal reaction. A histopathological image of the biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry was positive for synaptophysin and mic 2. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing small round blue cells and immunohistochemistry (IHC) positive for synaptophysin and mic-2 point to a likely diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma. 

Ewing sarcoma is the 2nd most common bone sarcoma in children. The majority of the patients affected are usually <20 years of age. It has a slight male predominance. 

It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus and flat bones of the pelvis. The majority of Ewing sarcomas have t(11:22). 

Patients present with painful enlarging mass, fever, and anaemia. The affected area is usually tender, swollen, and warm. Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). 

A histopathological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows sheets of uniform, round cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes. These cells are of neuroectodermal origin and have minimal cytoplasm and abundant glycogen. When they are arranged around a central fibrillary core in the form of clusters, the appearance is termed Homer-Wright rosettes. Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for synaptophysin and mic-2.

Given below is the histopathological appearance of Ewing sarcoma. 

As tumor cells are rich in glycogen, they stain positive for periodic acid Schiff (PAS) stain however, they stain negatively for reticulin.

Radiological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. Deposition of periosteal reaction in layers gives an onion-peel appearance (shown below). 

Other options:

Option A: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone. The histological features of osteosarcoma include pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant mitoses. The diagnosis is definitive with the presence of malignant tumor cells producing unmineralized osteoid or mineralized bone arranged in a typically fine, lacelike pattern.

X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunray appearance as shown below.

Option C: Neuroblastoma is a tumor of the sympathetic ganglia and adrenal medulla. It is derived from primordial neural crest cells. It is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood. On histopathology, small round blue cells are seen. These cells are concentrically arranged around a faintly eosinophilic fibrillary material (neuropil). This appearance is called Homer-Wright pseudorosettes

Option D: Osteoclastoma is also known as a giant cell tumour. The tumor cells are primitive osteoblast precursors and express high levels of RANKL. Histologically, the tumors consist of osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei. These cells are usually present against a backdrop of mononuclear stromal cells as shown below.

The image below shows an X-ray of a giant cell tumour showing the typical soap bubble appearance.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the outpatient department with fever, epigastric discomfort, progressive weight loss, arthralgia, and foul-smelling diarrhea for the past 6 months. There is no relation between the abdominal pain and his bowel movements. He was started on a restrictive diet, which showed no improvement. His biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of this patient along with the given slide showing macrophages filled with PAS-positive inclusions point to a diagnosis of Whipple's disease.

The morphologic hallmark of Whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by a gram-positive bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It is characterized by a triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia. Malabsorptive diarrhea of Whipple's disease is due to bacteria-laden macrophages that accumulate within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes causing lymphatic obstruction. Extraintestinal symptoms may precede malabsorption.

Histopathological findings: 

  • A dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages is seen in the small intestinal lamina propria; these macrophages contain PAS-positive, diastase-resistant granules, which indicate partially digested bacteria with lysosomes—a hallmark of Whipple's disease.
  • With disease progression, there is villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and apoptosis of surface epithelial cells in the intestine, which can cause diarrhoea due to decreased absorption and increased efflux of water and solutes.
  • Non-caseating granulomas may also be seen.
  • Bacteria-laden macrophages can accumulate within mesenteric lymph nodes, synovial membranes, cardiac valves, brain, or other sites.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is primarily established by endoscopic biopsy and histological evaluation. The remainder of the cases are diagnosed by PCR which can be done on duodenal biopsies or fluids (such as CSF and synovial fluid) or tissues.

Other options:

Option A: Irritable bowel syndrome presents with recurrent abdominal pain that may be related to defecation, associated with a change in frequency, or associated with a change in appearance. Despite having these symptoms, the endoscopy and microscopic examination are normal in patients with irritable bowel syndrome.

Option C: Cystic fibrosis is a congenital disorder due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7. It leads to abnormal transport of chloride and bicarbonate ions in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, and reproductive tract. 

Option D: Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy where there is an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria which subsequently impairs various nutrient absorption.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child with weakness of limbs and difficulty in walking was evaluated. Serum creatinine kinase was elevated. A sex-linked recessive mode of inheritance was seen.  What is the condition the boy is suffering from?
questions.solution:
A 3-year-old male child with limb weakness, difficulty walking, elevated creatinine kinase, and sex-linked inheritance is likely to suffer from Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

It is an X-linked recessive disease and is due to a mutation in a structural protein called dystrophin. Males are commonly affected. They are normal at birth. Symptoms of weakness gradually develop and are often characterized by delayed walking, clumsiness, and inability to keep up with peers. 

Pelvic girdle muscles are affected and this is followed by shoulder girdle weakness. Muscles of the lower leg are weak but enlarged, described as pseudohypertrophy. Other features include cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, and intellectual disability.

Serum creatine kinase is markedly elevated. Supportive treatment is needed. 

Other options:

Option A: Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting multiple systems. It is associated with skeletal muscle weakness, cataracts, endocrinopathy, and cardiomyopathy.

Option B: A limb-girdle dystrophy is a heterogeneous group characterized by autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant types. It is characterized by proximal muscle weakness with variable age of onset and severity

Option C: Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant type characterized by weakness of facial muscles and shoulder girdle.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors?
questions.solution:
NRG-1 (Neuregulin-1) is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs).

GIST are the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, the stomach being the most common site. They arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal, the pacemaker cells of the GIT. GIST is seen in the 5th to 6th decade of life and has an equal preponderance among males and females. Most patients present with haematemesis, melena, or vague abdominal pain. The most common indications for surgery include bleeding and obstruction.

The GIST may occur in a sporadic form or as part of familial syndromes. In sporadic GIST, the most common mutations seen are gain-of-function mutation in KIT (75-80%) and PDGFRA mutation (8%). Microscopically, GIST has elongated spindle cells or plumper epithelioid cells, or a mixed pattern.

The below image shows the microscopy of GIST composed of bundles, or fascicles, of spindle-shaped tumor cells.

Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient GIST is a subset of wild-type GIST seen with Carney triad or Carney-Stratakis syndrome. 

Imatinib can be used to treat GIST with mutations in KIT or PDGFRA. Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) - deficient GIST is imatinib-resistant, so sunitinib, sorafenib, or regorafenib can be used instead. 

During surgical resection of GIST, care must be taken to prevent capsule rupture, which causes seeding of nearby tissues leading to relapse in 100% of the cases. If capsule rupture occurs, adjuvant therapy with imatinib is indicated regardless of tumor extent.

Other options:

Option A: KIT (CD117): This is the most well-known marker for GISTs. About 85% of GISTs show mutations in the KIT gene, leading to the expression of the KIT protein on the cell surface. KIT is a receptor tyrosine kinase, and its activation is a key driver in the pathogenesis of GISTs.

Option B: SDH (Succinate Dehydrogenase): SDH mutations are associated with a subset of GISTs, particularly those that are KIT and PDGFRA wild-type. Loss of SDH function is characteristic of this subgroup, and SDH deficiency can be demonstrated through immunohistochemistry.

Option C: PDGFRA (Platelet-Derived Growth Factor Receptor Alpha): Mutations in the PDGFRA gene account for approximately 5-10% of GISTs. Similar to KIT, PDGFRA is a receptor tyrosine kinase, and mutations in this gene can lead to the development of GISTs.

questions.text: Massive splenomegaly is not seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
All the above are associated with massive splenomegaly except aplastic anemia.

Aplastic anemia is a syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure. This results in pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia). Important causes include 

  • Alkylating agents, antimetabolites
  • Benzene
  • Whole-body irradiation
  • Viral infections: Hepatitis (unknown virus), Cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, Herpes zoster
  • Fanconi anemia

The patient will have

  • Decreased red blood cells leading to anemia
  • Decreased white blood cells leading to recurrent infections
  • Decreased platelets lead to petechiae and ecchymoses.

Many other leukemias and lymphomas may have a similar presentation. However, splenomegaly is characteristically absent in these patients. 

The bone marrow is markedly hypocellular. It is largely devoid of hematopoietic cells. Marrow aspirates yield a dry tap having only fat cells, fibrous stroma, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. Aplasia is best appreciated in marrow biopsies. The following image shows a hypocellular bone marrow with little hematopoiesis and several fat cells.

Stem cell transplantation is the treatment of choice in those with a suitable donor. Immunosuppressive therapy is responsive in old patients or in patients without suitable donors.

Other options:

Option A: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm with the presence of BCR-ABL fusion gene translocation mutation. The marrow is markedly hypercellular because of increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursor cells. This results in decreased hematopoiesis within the bone marrow. The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis. Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

Option C: Hairy cell leukemia is a memory B-cell neoplasm predominantly seen in middle-aged male patients. It occurs due to activating BRAF mutations. Infiltration of the bone marrow, liver, and spleen with tumor cells results in splenomegaly. Sometimes, this can be the only finding in the patient. Pancytopenia results from marrow involvement.

Hairy cells have round, oblong, or reniform nuclei and moderate amounts of pale blue cytoplasm with thread-like or bleb-like extensions. Immunophenotyping shows hairy cell leukemias typically express the pan-B-cell markers CD19 and CD20 and certain relatively distinctive markers, such as CD11c, CD25, CD103, and annexin A1.

 Option D: Lymphomas cause splenomegaly due to the infiltration of neoplastic cells in the spleen.

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections met with a road traffic accident and requires a blood transfusion. Immediately after starting a blood transfusion, the child develops severe anaphylactic reactions. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause such manifestations?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with recurrent respiratory infections and developing a severe anaphylactic reaction immediately after starting a blood transfusion is suggestive of Isolated IgA deficiency.

Isolated IgA deficiency is the most common primary immunodeficiency disorder. Here, the B cells fail to mature into IgA plasma cells and this leads to decreased levels of IgA with normal levels of IgG and IgM. Most of the patients are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients develop recurrent respiratory infections, diarrhoea and rarely auto-immune diseases like SLE and rheumatoid arthritis. 

Patients with IgA deficiency are at risk of severe anaphylactic reactions associated with blood transfusion containing normal IgA. IgA-deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components can be used to prevent allergic reactions in individuals with IgA Deficiency.

Treatment of severe anaphylaxis involves stopping the transfusion. Vascular access is maintained and administration of 0.3–0.5 mg of adrenaline is done. Administration of steroids, antihistamine drugs, and bronchodilators are done.

Other options:

Option B: Hyper IgM syndrome is due to deficient CD40L on T-cells. B-cells have CD40 on their surface which interacts with CD40L on T-cells to undergo class switching from IgM to various other classes (IgG, IgA, IgE) depending on the type of antigen. Thus, failure of this class switching leads to an increase in IgM and a decrease in other classes of antibodies. Clinically, patients present with recurrent pyogenic infections, because the level of opsonizing IgG antibodies is low.

Option C: DiGeorge syndrome is caused due to deletion of chromosome 22q11. It leads to loss of T cell-mediated immunity and the characteristic features are (Mnemonic CATCH-22) Cardiac abnormality, abnormal facies, thymic aplasia, cleft palate and hypocalcemia. Absent thymus in this condition causes recurrent infections. 

Option D: Bruton's X-linked agammaglobulinemia is due to a defect in Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK), which is required for the maturation of pre-B cells. Thus the defect leads to the arrest of maturation of pre-B cells and a decrease in the number of mature B cells. There will be decreased IgM, IgG, IgA levels leading to recurrent infections.

questions.text:
Match the following cells with their locations.
1. Kupffer cells a. Stomach
2. Parietal cells b. Liver 
3. Dust cells c. Alveoli
4. Clara cells d. Bronchioles
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set of the cells and their locations is 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d.

Kupffer cells are a component of the mononuclear phagocytic system and are located in the liver.

Parietal cells, also called oxyntic cells, are found in the upper half of the gastric glands. They have numerous mitochondria and are actively involved in the secretion of hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor - a glycoprotein that aids in the absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. 

Dust cells are macrophages in the walls of the alveoli. They phagocytose dust particles in the alveoli. In CHF these macrophages phagocytose erythrocytes that escape from the capillaries. The cells acquire a brick-red color and are called heart failure cells.

Clara cells are non-ciliated cuboidal epithelial cells that secrete important defense markers and serve as stem cells after injury. These cells make up a larger portion of the epithelial lining in the later portions of the conducting airway.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presented 3 months ago with mild behavioral changes. He developed startle myoclonus and progressively worsening dementia. His condition deteriorated rapidly and the patient passed away within 2 days. On autopsy, spongiform degeneration of the brain was noted. What inclusions could also be found on histopathological examination of his brain?
questions.solution:
This elderly man, with startle myoclonus, a rapidly progressive dementia that leads to death within 3 months, and spongiform degeneration of the brain on autopsy most likely had a diagnosis of prion disease (likely Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease or Kuru). Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is associated with misfolded prion protein inclusions called PrP.

Prion disease is a rapidly progressing neurodegenerative disorder that occurs due to abnormal protein folding of prion proteins. These proteins can undergo a structural change from an alpha helix to beta-pleated sheets (PrPC to PrPSc). These proteins now become resistant to breakdown by normal proteases in the body and can rapidly spread, invading the central nervous system and inducing neuronal cell death. Prion diseases can be sporadic in nature, but more often they have a familial mode of spread due to mutations in the PRNP gene that codes for PrP.

The brain classically undergoes spongiform degeneration due to vacuole formation and rapid death of the neurons. Histopathological examination during post-mortem can reveal inclusion such as PrPSC deposits and Kuru plaques. 

Other options:

Option B: Alpha-synuclein is commonly seen in Parkinson's disease, which presents with an abnormal shuffling gait, resting tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. It can also be seen in multiple system atrophy which is predominantly a disease of autonomic dysfunction. It can progress rapidly but is not associated with startle myoclonus or progressive dementia.

Option C: Tau neurofibrillary tangles are often seen in Alzheimer's disease and frontotemporal lobe degeneration. Both these conditions do not present with rapid worsening of symptoms as seen in this patient. Alzheimer's disease causes gradually progressive dementia and presents with myoclonic jerks only at later stages. Frontotemporal lobe degeneration would result in gradual behavioral changes and features of aphasia.

Option D: Polyglutamate aggregates are seen in Huntington's disease. This disorder presents with a gradual onset of dementia and abnormal movements that progress to death over 20 years.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with recurrent ear infections and a skin rash. During the workup, the finding below is seen on electron microscopy. What other marker will likely be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Birbeck granules are cytoplasmic organelles that are characteristic of Langerhans cells histioctyosis. S100 is a family of proteins that are also expressed by Langerhans cells. Therefore, a patient with Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is likely to have a positive S100 test.

Histopathologically, it is characterized by the presence of Langerhans cells. The tumour cells contain abundant cytoplasm with folded or grooved nuclei. Ultrastructurally, they contain tennis-racket-shaped intracytoplasmic inclusions called Birbeck granules. The tumour cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

The most common gene mutated in LCH is the BRAF gene. Activation of the valine-to-glutamate substitution at residue 600 in BRAF gene is seen in LCH. Less common mutations have also been detected in TP53, RAS, and the receptor tyrosine kinase MET. 

BRAF mutations are also seen in conditions like hairy cell leukaemia, colon adenocarcinoma, melanoma, papillary thyroid carcinoma. 

LCH is a spectrum of clonal proliferations of immature dendritic cells called the Langerhans cells. It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can also infiltrate nearly every organ, like the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. 

LCH can present as the following clinical entities: Multifocal multisystem LCH (Letterer-Siwe disease) - mostly seen in infants
Unifocal and multifocal unisystem LCH (eosinophilic granuloma)- The combination of bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos is called the Hand-Schüller-Christian triad - mostly seen in older children, adults
Pulmonary LCH - mostly seen in adults

Clinical features include: Often asymptomatic. Dyspnea, cough, bone pain, abnormal growth of soft tissue over the affected bone, rash, pruritus, increased thirst, and lymphadenopathy.
Fatigue, generalized weakness, weight loss, night sweats, nausea, and fever may also occur.

Other important markers:

  • GATA3: Primary lung adenocarcinoma, small cell carcinoma, thyroid neoplasms both primary and metaplastic
  • Chromogranin: Neuroendocrine tumors (Option A)
  • CD117: GIST Tumors, Mast cell tumors, malignant melanoma, clear cell sarcoma (Option D)
  • CD1a: Histiocytosis X
  • Calretinin: Adrenal cortical neoplasm, mesothelial origin tumors, sex-chord stromal tumors (Option B)
  • Desmin: Rhabdomyosarcoma, smooth muscle tumor
  • Vimentin: Pancreatic cancer, endometrial carcinoma
  • S100: Urothelial carcinoma, Melanoma, Pancreatic ductal carcinoma, Chordoma, Histocytosis X

questions.text: A peripheral smear of a patient having myelodysplastic syndrome is shown below. Identify the finding.
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows pseudo-pledger huet cells (neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes and occasionally neutrophils that completely lack nuclear segmentation) which are seen in myelodysplastic syndrome. 

Myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects, associated with ineffective hematopoiesis.

It is of two types:

  • Primary MDS - develops slowly, usually after 50 years of age.
  • Secondary or therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) - develops 2 to 8 years after the toxic drug or radiation exposure with a poor prognosis

Patients usually present with weakness, infections, and hemorrhages due to pancytopenia. Both types of MDS have a high risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, the most frequent and rapid transformation occurs in therapy-related MDS (t-MDS).

Other options:

Option A: Ringed sideroblasts are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules in Prussian blue stained aspirates or biopsy.

Option B: Pawn ball megakaryocytes are megakaryocytes with single nuclear lobes or multiple separate nuclei.

Option C: Dohle bodies represent the dilated endoplasmic reticulum. They appear as blue-colored inclusions inside neutrophils. These inclusions may be seen in conditions such as sepsis and myelodysplastic syndromes.

Related Pearl: Marrow Changes in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

The myelodysplastic syndrome can lead to dysplasia of the erythroid series, myeloid series, and megakaryocytes.

Dysplasia of erythroid series appears as

  • Ring sideroblasts- Erythroblasts with stainable iron in the cytoplasm
  • Megaloblastoid maturation- Abnormally large erythroid cells
  • Nuclear budding abnormalities- Nucleus with abnormal shape

 

Dysplasia of myeloid series 

  • Neutrophils with a decreased number of secondary granules
  • Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet cells- neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes

 

Dysplasia of the megakaryocytes- 

  • Megakaryocyte with single nuclear lobe
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes- cells with multiple separate nuclei

If only one lineage is affected, then it is called single lineage dysplasia. If multiple lineages are affected, then it is called multilineage dysplasia. If the percentage of ring sideroblasts is more than 15% it is called MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS).

questions.text: A young person with recurrent seasonal conjunctivitis presents with itchiness and watering in the eyes. What is the most likely cell involved in the immediate phase of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of allergic reactions suggest Type 1 hypersensitivity which is mediated by immunoglobulin E (IgE) binding to mast cells.

Immediate (Type I) Hypersensitivity, also called allergic reactions or allergies is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to an IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It has two phases.

Early phase: The mediators produced by the mast cells are responsible for most of the immediate hypersensitivity reactions. Histamine and leukotrienes are released rapidly from the sensitized mast cells and trigger intense immediate reactions characterized by edema, mucus secretion, and smooth muscle spasm.

Other mediators involved in the early phase are, 

  • Enzymes: neutral proteases (chymase, tryptase) and acid hydrolases
  • Proteoglycans: heparin and chondroitin sulfate
  • Lipid mediators: Platelet-activating factor (PAF)

Late-phase: The late-phase reaction is characterized by the recruitment of leukocytes, that amplify and sustain the inflammatory response without exposure to the triggering antigen.

Mediators involved in the late phase of type 1 hypersensitivity reaction are:

  • Cytokines: TNF, IL-1, IL-4, IL-5, and chemokines (eotaxin)
  • Leukocytes (eosinophils)
  • Major Basic Protein (MBP)
  • Eosinophil cationic protein

The sequence of events in immediate (type 1) hypersensitivity

Though eosinophils and neutrophils are involved later in the pathogenesis, mast cells are central to the development of immediate hypersensitivity.

questions.text: A patient who underwent renal transplantation 8 months ago presents with pain at the site of the transplanted kidney, fever, and malaise. The renal biopsy findings of the kidney allograft are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of acute pyelonephritis after 8 months of kidney transplantation and the image showing enlarged tubular epithelial cells, nuclear inclusions, and interstitial inflammation suggest nephropathy caused by polyomavirus.

Polyomavirus is a viral pathogen causing pyelonephritis in kidney allografts. Immunosuppression of the allograft recipient can lead to reactivation of latent infection by polyomavirus and the development of nephropathy. This form of pyelonephritis is referred to as polyomavirus nephropathy.

Histopathology shows infection of tubular epithelial cell nuclei, leading to nuclear enlargement and intranuclear inclusions visible by light microscopy. An inflammatory interstitial inflammatory response is present.
